intro: Blakea bracteata subsp. ecuadorensis, commonly known as the Ecuadorian blakea, is a species of flowering plant in the Malvaceae family. It is native to the Andean regions of Ecuador and is characterized by its striking, showy flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows as an epiphyte or terrestrial shrub, often found in humid, shaded environments. Its leaves are ovate to elliptical, with a smooth or slightly hairy surface, and it produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small seeds. This subspecies is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
